subject: Critical Thinking
title: How Courts Use Logic: Beyond Reasonable Doubt
description: A 60-second lesson on How Courts Use Logic: Beyond Reasonable Doubt.

hook.text: A jury doesn't need to be certain. They need to find no reasonable doubt. That's a logical standard.

buildup.text: Criminal law uses deduction: the law says X is illegal. The defendant did X. Therefore, guilty. In theory.

discovery.text: But establishing 'the defendant did X' relies on induction â€” witness testimony, forensic evidence, probability.

twist.text: 'Beyond reasonable doubt' is deliberately vague. Studies show jurors interpret it anywhere from 70% to 99%.

climax.text: The legal system mixes deduction, induction, and abduction â€” often without knowing which it's using.

punchline.text: Justice depends on logic. But the logic is messier than it looks.

quiz.question: What type of reasoning establishes that 'the defendant did X'?
